sourcesContent:
import React from 'react'
  import { MDXTag } from '@mdx-js/tag'
  

export default class MDXContent extends React.Component {
  constructor(props) {
    super(props)
    this.layout = null
  }
  render() {
    const { components, ...props } = this.props

    return <MDXTag
             name="wrapper"
             
             components={components}><MDXTag name="h1" components={components} props={{"id":"regression-model-performance"}}>{`Regression Model Performance`}</MDXTag>
{/* TOC */}
<MDXTag name="ul" components={components}>
<MDXTag name="li" components={components} parentName="ul"><MDXTag name="a" components={components} parentName="li" props={{"href":"#regression-model-performance"}}>{`Regression Model Performance`}</MDXTag><MDXTag name="ul" components={components} parentName="li">
<MDXTag name="li" components={components} parentName="ul"><MDXTag name="a" components={components} parentName="li" props={{"href":"#r-squared-intuition"}}>{`R-Squared Intuition`}</MDXTag></MDXTag>
<MDXTag name="li" components={components} parentName="ul"><MDXTag name="a" components={components} parentName="li" props={{"href":"#adjusted-r-squared-intuition"}}>{`Adjusted R-Squared Intuition`}</MDXTag></MDXTag>
<MDXTag name="li" components={components} parentName="ul"><MDXTag name="a" components={components} parentName="li" props={{"href":"#evaluating-regression-models-performance"}}>{`Evaluating Regression Models Performance`}</MDXTag></MDXTag>
<MDXTag name="li" components={components} parentName="ul"><MDXTag name="a" components={components} parentName="li" props={{"href":"#interpretting-linear-regressions-coefficients"}}>{`Interpretting Linear Regressions Coefficients`}</MDXTag></MDXTag>
</MDXTag></MDXTag>
</MDXTag>
{/* /TOC */}
<MDXTag name="h2" components={components} props={{"id":"r-squared-intuition"}}>{`R-Squared Intuition`}</MDXTag>
<MDXTag name="p" components={components}>{`Interesting parameter and most people use it without understanding the underlying principles.`}</MDXTag>
<MDXTag name="p" components={components}>{`We spoke about the `}<MDXTag name="inlineCode" components={components} parentName="p">{`simple linear regression`}</MDXTag>{` model being the result of the `}<MDXTag name="inlineCode" components={components} parentName="p">{`ordinary least squares`}</MDXTag>{` method. This is also known as `}<MDXTag name="inlineCode" components={components} parentName="p">{`sum of squares residuals`}</MDXTag>{` and is given as `}<MDXTag name="inlineCode" components={components} parentName="p">{`SS[res]`}</MDXTag>{`.`}</MDXTag>
<MDXTag name="p" components={components}>{`If we instead took `}<MDXTag name="inlineCode" components={components} parentName="p">{`SUM(y[i] - y[avg])^2`}</MDXTag>{`, we get the `}<MDXTag name="inlineCode" components={components} parentName="p">{`total sum of squares SS[tot]`}</MDXTag>{`. To get our regression, we get `}<MDXTag name="inlineCode" components={components} parentName="p">{`R^2 = 1 - (SS[res]/SS[tot])`}</MDXTag>{`.`}</MDXTag>
<MDXTag name="p" components={components}>{`As you minimize the SS`}{`[res]`}{`, it becomes smaller, and as we get `}<MDXTag name="inlineCode" components={components} parentName="p">{`1 - (SS[res]/SS[tot])`}</MDXTag>{` we actually start to get closer to 1. The closer we get to 1, the better. Can R^2 be negative? Yes. It can if the SS`}{`[res]`}{` fits the line worse. In that case it would be better to use the average than the model - although it would be hard to do!`}</MDXTag>
<MDXTag name="h2" components={components} props={{"id":"adjusted-r-squared-intuition"}}>{`Adjusted R-Squared Intuition`}</MDXTag>
<MDXTag name="p" components={components}>{`This is the fun part!`}</MDXTag>
<MDXTag name="p" components={components}>{`Here we have our `}<MDXTag name="inlineCode" components={components} parentName="p">{`simple linear regression`}</MDXTag>{` regression from before. We, the same concepts apply for multiple linear regression.`}</MDXTag>
<MDXTag name="p" components={components}>{`R^2 - goodness of fit. The closer the one, the better - BUT the problem is when we start adding more IVs into the model. What we can look at is whether the R^2 getting better or worse, but because of SS`}{`[res]`}{` the minimum will never decrease. `}<MDXTag name="strong" components={components} parentName="p">{`THIS IS IMPORTANT`}</MDXTag>{`.`}</MDXTag>
<MDXTag name="p" components={components}>{`Once you add a new variable, it will affect what the variable looks like. Either the new variable will help minimize the SS`}{`[res]`}{`. If you cannot decress SS`}{`[res]`}{`, the new variable would be zero (unlikely).`}</MDXTag>
<MDXTag name="p" components={components}>{`Therefore, `}<MDXTag name="inlineCode" components={components} parentName="p">{`R^2`}</MDXTag>{` will never decrease when you add in more variables. That being said, if the IV has zero correlation or causation with the DV, there randomly will be a slight correlation - therefore R^2 might slightly increase even though the variable is not helping the model.`}</MDXTag>
<MDXTag name="p" components={components}>{`This is where `}<MDXTag name="inlineCode" components={components} parentName="p">{`adjusted R^2`}</MDXTag>{` comes in.`}</MDXTag>
<MDXTag name="pre" components={components}><MDXTag name="code" components={components} parentName="pre" props={{}}>{`Adj R^2 = 1 - (1-R^2)*((n - 1)/(n - p - 1))
p - number of regressors
n - sample size
`}</MDXTag></MDXTag>
<MDXTag name="p" components={components}>{`This formula will penalise you for adding in IVs that have no correlation.`}</MDXTag>
<MDXTag name="h2" components={components} props={{"id":"evaluating-regression-models-performance"}}>{`Evaluating Regression Models Performance`}</MDXTag>
<MDXTag name="p" components={components}>{`Reflecting back on the `}<MDXTag name="inlineCode" components={components} parentName="p">{`Backward Elimination`}</MDXTag>{` process that we used, we actually came to a feeling that we shouldn't have excluded the last value of `}<MDXTag name="inlineCode" components={components} parentName="p">{`Marketing Spend`}</MDXTag>{`.`}</MDXTag>
<MDXTag name="p" components={components}>{`The problem with the algorithms that we chose and the p value threshhold we chose is that the threshhold is arbitrary.`}</MDXTag>
<MDXTag name="p" components={components}>{`What we can actually find at the bottom of those same reports that we used is that it also gives us the values of `}<MDXTag name="inlineCode" components={components} parentName="p">{`R-squared`}</MDXTag>{` and `}<MDXTag name="inlineCode" components={components} parentName="p">{`Adjusted R-squared`}</MDXTag>{`.`}</MDXTag>
<MDXTag name="p" components={components}>{`If we observe this as we build our model in code, then we can use the report to help check the goodness of fit.`}</MDXTag>
<MDXTag name="h2" components={components} props={{"id":"interpretting-linear-regressions-coefficients"}}>{`Interpretting Linear Regressions Coefficients`}</MDXTag>
<MDXTag name="p" components={components}>{`If we look at the third model and look at the IVs. If we change the IV value, we should be able to tell that DV should correlate in a certain direction.`}</MDXTag>
<MDXTag name="p" components={components}>{`The coefficients come under their own heading.`}</MDXTag>
<MDXTag name="p" components={components}>{`We should be able to ue logistics just for this. Magnitude can also trip you up. The `}<MDXTag name="inlineCode" components={components} parentName="p">{`Estimate`}</MDXTag>{` value doesn't really give you more indication. We could alter the value of input and it would change values for `}<MDXTag name="inlineCode" components={components} parentName="p">{`Estimate`}</MDXTag>{` etc. Think of magnitude in term of units of the IV.`}</MDXTag>
<MDXTag name="p" components={components}>{`What the estimate shows that for every unit you increase, the IV would increase by a certain amount.`}</MDXTag>
<MDXTag name="p" components={components}><MDXTag name="strong" components={components} parentName="p">{`THE IMPORTANT PART: THING IN TERMS OF PER UNIT`}</MDXTag></MDXTag>
<MDXTag name="p" components={components}>{`You'll also know that as you take out certain IVs, the actual effect that it brings into the model will also change.`}</MDXTag>
           </MDXTag>
  }
}
